results.headline: Magic and Mayhem From a Video Game
results.summary_short: Like actors in an amateur stage play, the large, mostly all-star — or has-been star — cast of “In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale” look, rather dazedly, to be playing dress-up.
results.display_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale

results.headline: A Youthful Awakening to Mother Nature’s Laws in a Turkish Village
results.summary_short: Livestock far outnumber humans in “Times and Winds,” Reha Erdem’s transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Times and Winds

results.headline: For Values-Based Produce, a Heroic Seafaring Quest
results.summary_short: “The Pirates Who Don’t Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie” is a rather ordinary film with faith at its core.
results.display_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie

results.headline: Mend Your Foolish Ways, Would-Be Church Bandits
results.summary_short: In “First Sunday,” Ice Cube departs a bit from the upright-citizen persona, playing a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Sunday

results.headline: Down and Out and Running Numbers in the Rougher Precincts of Manila
results.summary_short: Much like man’s best friend, the rough-hewn Filipino movie “The Bet Collector” chases its protagonist from step to step, misery to misery, all but nipping at her heels.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bet Collector

results.headline: Two Drifting Life Rafts on a Sea of Circumstance
results.summary_short: There’s not a single wrong note in “Liberty Kid,” Ilya Chaiken’s poignant drama about marginal lives strained to breaking by the aftermath of Sept. 11.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Liberty Kid

results.headline: Him, Her and Him by the Seashore, Balancing Levity and Suffering
results.summary_short: “Woman on the Beach” is a bittersweet accounting of the geography of desire.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Woman on the Beach

results.headline: American Motherhood and the Question of Home Birth
results.summary_short: “The Business of Being Born” is a passionate ground-level examination of home childbirth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Business of Being Born

results.headline: Brutishness Begets Brutishness on the Road
results.summary_short: “A Bloody Aria,” by the Korean director Won Shin-yun, is a sort of Asian “Deliverance.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Bloody Aria

results.headline: Death Is on the Line; Can You Hear It Now?
results.summary_short: “One Missed Call” is the latest Japanese knockoff to fetishize death by technology.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Missed Call

results.headline: John Lennon’s Death Revisited Through the Words of His Killer
results.summary_short: Andrew Piddington’s devastating re-enactment of events leading up to, including and immediately after the murder is taken from interviews, depositions and court transcripts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Killing of John Lennon

results.headline: The Ghost Down the Hall Is Scary in Spanish, Too
results.summary_short: “The Orphanage,” a diverting, overwrought ghost story from Spain, relies on basic and durable horror movie techniques.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Orphanage

results.headline: Way Down in Harmony, With Mythic Blues Again
results.summary_short: “Honeydripper,” directed by John Sayles, is a shambling fusion of pop mythology and social mosaic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Honeydripper

results.headline: Sunshine Daydream, With Pointed Point of View
results.summary_short: “Smiley Face,” about a pot-addled would-be actress stumbling through a long, weird day in Los Angeles, is a contradiction in terms: a “stoner” comedy with a purpose.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smiley Face

results.headline: Master Portraitist, Writ Large Himself
results.summary_short: “Chuck Close,” about the painter, photographer and printmaker by the documentary filmmaker Marion Cajori, truly excels in its depiction of the physical process of making art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chuck Close

results.headline: An American Primitive, Forged in a Crucible of Blood and Oil
results.summary_short: “There Will Be Blood,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s epic American nightmare, arrives belching fire and brimstone and damnation to hell.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of There Will Be Blood

results.headline: Aliens and Predators Still Can’t Seem to Get Along
results.summary_short: The second “Aliens vs. Predator” film is, like its predecessor, one very dark movie. Not psychologically dark; dark  dark, as in not very generously lighted.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem

results.headline: In a Flat World, a Rebel With a Cause
results.summary_short: “Persepolis,” austere as it may look, is full of warmth and surprise, alive with humor and a fierce independence of spirit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Persepolis

results.headline: Fearsome Nessie Started Out as a Good Egg and Playmate
results.summary_short: Many lonely children yearn for a pet to call their own. In “The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep,” based on a novel by Dick King-Smith, a boy finds not only that, but a best friend as well.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Water Horse

results.headline: Leading the Charge to Inspire Underdogs
results.summary_short: There are enough things to admire about “The Great Debaters,” the heavily fictionalized true story of The Little Debate Team That Could, that your impulse is to forgive the movie its shortcomings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Debaters
